title: Kirk Saarloos
text:
Kirk Craig Saarloos (born May 23, 1979) is an American <a href="baseball">baseball</a> coach and former <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a>, who is the current head baseball coach of the <a href="TCU%20Horned%20Frogs%20baseball">TCU Horned Frogs</a>. He played <a href="college%20baseball">college baseball</a> at <a href="Cal%20State%20Fullerton%20Titans%20baseball">Cal State Fullerton</a> for coach <a href="George%20Horton%20%28baseball%29">George Horton</a> from 1999 to 2001 and played in <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> (MLB) for 7 seasons from 2002 to 2008. 
The <a href="Houston%20Astros">Houston Astros</a> selected Saarloos in the third round of the <a href="2001%20Major%20League%20Baseball%20Draft">2001 Major League Baseball Draft</a>. He played 7 years a pitcher in the MLB, with Houston from 2002 to 2003, the <a href="Oakland%20Athletics">Oakland Athletics</a> 2004 to 2006, <a href="Cincinnati%20Reds">Cincinnati Reds</a> in 2007 before returning to Oakland in 2008.
High school and college.
Saarloos graduated from <a href="Valley%20Christian%20High%20School%20%28Cerritos%2C%20California%29">Valley Christian High School</a> in <a href="Cerritos%2C%20California">Cerritos, California</a>, where he was a three-sport (<a href="baseball">baseball</a>, <a href="American%20football">football</a> and <a href="soccer">soccer</a>) athlete. He attended <a href="California%20State%20University%2C%20Fullerton">California State University, Fullerton</a>, where he established himself as one of the best closers in <a href="college%20baseball">college baseball</a> during his sophomore and junior seasons. In 1999, he played <a href="collegiate%20summer%20baseball">collegiate summer baseball</a> with the <a href="Cotuit%20Kettleers">Cotuit Kettleers</a> of the <a href="Cape%20Cod%20Baseball%20League">Cape Cod Baseball League</a>. In , his senior year, he became a starter (the new closer was former <a href="Washington%20Nationals">Washington Nationals</a> closer <a href="Chad%20Cordero">Chad Cordero</a>) and established himself as the <a href="Ace%20%28baseball%29">ace</a> of the staff, winning 15 games with a 2.18 <a href="Earned%20run%20average">ERA</a>. He was drafted by the <a href="Houston%20Astros">Houston Astros</a> in the <a href="2001%20Major%20League%20Baseball%20Draft">2001 Major League Baseball Draft</a> in the third round as the 86th overall pick.
Professional career.
Saarloos quickly rose in the Astros organization, making brief stops at Double-A <a href="Round%20Rock%20Express">Round Rock</a> and <a href="Minor%20league%20baseball">Triple-A</a> <a href="New%20Orleans%20Zephyrs">New Orleans</a> before being called up to the major leagues in his second year as a professional. In , he went 6-7 with a 6.01 <a href="Earned%20run%20average">ERA</a> with Houston and was sent down to New Orleans for the next season. In , he again pitched very well in the minors but posted a 4.93 <a href="Earned%20run%20average">ERA</a> in 36 games for the big club. He also contributed to the Astros' six-pitcher <a href="no-hitter">no-hitter</a> of the <a href="New%20York%20Yankees">New York Yankees</a> on June 11, throwing the last out of the third inning and all of the fourth. It was around this time he caught the eye of <a href="Oakland%20Athletics">Oakland Athletics</a> assistant general manager <a href="Paul%20DePodesta">Paul DePodesta</a>. A few weeks into the season, after appearing in only two games for New Orleans, he was traded to the Athletics for <a href="Chad%20Harville">Chad Harville</a>. They sent him to Triple-A <a href="Sacramento%20River%20Cats">Sacramento</a>, where he pitched well enough to receive a call-up and start five games for Oakland.
In , with <a href="Mark%20Mulder">Mark Mulder</a> and <a href="Tim%20Hudson">Tim Hudson</a> traded away, the Athletics had openings in their rotation. Saarloos beat out <a href="Keiichi%20Yabu">Keiichi Yabu</a> and <a href="Juan%20Cruz%20%28baseball%29">Juan Cruz</a> to win the last starter spot in the rotation. Saarloos succeeded, going 10-9 with a 4.17 <a href="Earned%20run%20average">ERA</a> in 27 starts. He was widely considered to be among the best #5 starters in the <a href="American%20League">American League</a>, sporting one of the lowest home run rates.
With the signing of veteran starter <a href="Esteban%20Loaiza">Esteban Loaiza</a> before the season, the A's bumped Saarloos to the bullpen. Soon after, <a href="Rich%20Harden">Rich Harden</a> got injured, and Saarloos was put in as a fifth starter for a few games. He was also used in many varying relief roles, much like <a href="Justin%20Duchscherer">Justin Duchscherer</a> was in 2005, but also as a spot starter. Shifting between the bullpen and the rotation, Saarloos finished with a record of 7-7 in 35 games for the A's. He allowed more home runs (19) than the previous season (11). On January 19, , Saarloos signed a one-year $1.2 million deal with the Athletics.
On January 23, 2007, Saarloos was traded to the <a href="Cincinnati%20Reds">Cincinnati Reds</a> for minor league reliever <a href="David%20Shafer%20%28baseball%29">David Shafer</a>. Both teams also received a player to be named later. On May 28, 2007, Saarloos was sent to the minors after failing to retire any of the seven batters he faced in a 14-10 loss to the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Pirates">Pittsburgh Pirates</a> the night before. In his lone season with the Reds, Saarloos had a 7.17 ERA in 42.2 innings. On October 12, 2007, Saarloos was outrighted to the minor leagues. He refused the assignment and became a <a href="free%20agent">free agent</a>.
On January 15, , Saarloos signed a minor league contract with an invitation to <a href="spring%20training">spring training</a> with the Oakland Athletics. On April 14, he was added to the major league roster but was designated for assignment on April 23. He was sent outright to Triple-A on April 25. On August 18, Saarloos was recalled. He became a free agent at the end of the season.
Saarloos signed a minor league contract with an invitation to spring training with the <a href="Cleveland%20Indians">Cleveland Indians</a> in January ; after training camp, he was sent to <a href="Minor%20League">Minor League</a> camp on March 24, 2009. He went 3-10 in 16 games at the AAA level. He retired after the 2009 season.
Scouting.
Saarloos has a variety of pitches, including a four-seam <a href="fastball">fastball</a>, a <a href="curveball">curveball</a>, a <a href="Slider%20%28baseball%29">slider</a>, and a <a href="changeup">changeup</a>. However, his best pitch by far is his mid-to-high 80's <a href="Sinker%20%28baseball%29">sinker</a>. For this reason, Saarloos is known predominately as a sinkerball specialist and as such, gets few strikeouts (batters tend to hit groundballs when faced with a sinker). In fact, his 2.99 strikeouts per nine innings in 2005 ranked third to last in Major League Baseball and was the lowest mark in Oakland Athletics history for a starting pitcher.
Coaching career.
Saarloos was on the 2011 <a href="Cal%20State%20Fullerton%20Titans%20baseball">Cal State Fullerton</a> coaching staff as an undergraduate assistant coach. His primary duties were as pitching coach. Opposing teams batted .250 against his pitchers, and he coached <a href="Big%20West%20Conference">Big West</a> Pitcher of the Year <a href="Dylan%20Floro">Dylan Floro</a> and four Freshmen All-American pitchers. In 2012, Saarloos returned to Cal State Fullerton as their full-time pitching coach and assisted in recruiting. He became the pitching coach at <a href="TCU%20Horned%20Frogs%20baseball">Texas Christian University</a> in the summer of 2012. He led the team to the lowest ERA in school history since 1968.
He was named the head coach at TCU on June 15, 2021.
